div1.p:
One week from today will be "the second Saturday" and will no doubt see you gathered together for a meeting. Lida told me in her note that no August meeting was held as so many were away - I hope the summer has been a happy and restful one for you all and that the coming year will strengthen the bond of Pi Phi and see much accomplished. The fraternity means so much to the community here and has done so much good that it makes one feel that the
school is a great trust for which we can all work whether near or far away. These mountain people are very reserved and conservative and as one of there revival songs expresses it - "What was good enough for my father is good enough for me!" So that the coming generations whom we reach through the school are the ones who will really better conditions. But do not think that we teachers give without getting - for sometimes one wonders if there is not more of getting on our part after all. They are so hospitable and kind hearted - so pleased with simple things - so like big children in many ways - that you realize that there are some things they have that the busy outside
world has unfortunately grown away from. I'm getting quite philosphopical am I not and will now proceed to statements of what all we've been doing for the past month.

First as to the school itself - we have enrolled exactly ninety-two of which the girls have a little higher enrollment that the boys. They are not up to the standard of our schools in the West by any means - nor do they know how to settle down and study. On the other hand when you remember that many of them come from homes
where the parents are uneducatedilliterate, that they see no books or magazines except at school - that they do not come in contact with the outside world - not even as farnear as Sevierville fourteen miles away - that they have to stay out of school part of the time to help with the washing and ironing and field work - you wonder that they do as well as they do do!! (If my sentences get involved & full of repetition please overlook for I cannot take the time to send you a polished and elegantly written epistle.) I attended County Institute at Sevierville last Saturday - held in the assembly room of Murphy College. About thirty-five teachers were there - a small percent
I'm told of all the number in the county. When I gazed upon their youthful childlike faces (for most of them were in their teens or very early twenties) I did not wonder that wild stories circulated about the poor teaching and discipline and that the schools were in bad condition. The salaries are very very low also and it seems that politics plays a large part in school management. Our school is the best equipped in the county - so far.

We have at last a manual training
teacher - Mr. Cresswell from Jefferson County. He is very young but seems to be just the right man for the place. Since his arrival the boys' dormitory has been started and for the past two weeks he with three boys from Pigeon Forge and Mrs. Profit cook and housekeeper - have lived in the Maple house at the foot of our road. Wouldn't you like an outline of a day at school. Harrison the man about the place unlocks the building & starts the fires about 6 - and at 7:45 either Emily or I ring the first bell - we take turns - a week at a time - The boys play ball - the girls play a little but seem to prefer to sit around and talk - until eight o'clock when the last bell rings for "books" as they say. The whole
school gathers in my room - which is the largest and has the piano - for assembly or opening exercises presided over by one teacher for a week. Evelyn Bishop is usually present to play the piano & help with the singing. We have the flag salute at least once a week - several songs - Scripture reading - and the Lord's prayer. Miss Burton's primary class has acted a little play a couple of times - a quartet of boys sang once - another of girls - short talks by a visitor or something of that sort adds variety occasionally.

Then the little ones march to their room followed by Miss Runyan's fourth fifth and sixth graders and Mr. Cresswell takes his four mathematics classes and I my English & grammar. These latter are held in the sewing room which serves the purpose nicely with its tables benches and blackboard. By this time it is ten and a fifteen minute recess follows. One of the youngsters always takes our mail down to the postoffice at Charley Ogle's store during this interim. Next is spelling conducted by Mr. Cresswell and I have fifteen minutes breathing spell until 10:30 when my beginning Latin class consisting of four arrives - Mr. C. meanwhile conducting a
class in agriculture. After these he is through until 11:25 when he takes a geography class in Abbie Runyan's room so she can go home and help her two girls get dinner ready. I finish up the morning with geography and writing. From 1 to 2 I have U.S. History and ancient history - recess from 2:00 to 2:15. Then Mr. Cresswell and Abbie each have their manual training and domestic science every day (except Friday) until 3 dismal dismissal
time and I have the leftovers in my room to study. Usually I take the last fifteen minutes for games or reading of some kind.

A girls' club is organized now - consisting of girls from ten years up - and has a membership of about twenty-five - object good times and deeds of service. We have had a picnic - a darning party - a party for the boys here at the house - and this next week there is to be a marshmallow roast. The darning party was here after school last Monday and of course the very ones who couldn't darn failed to arrive. They are not keen about such things but all turned out for the party for the boys which was here last Friday evening.

It seems to take so much push to get things started here - and to rouse enthusiasm. We try to make the girls feel that it's their club and that they are the ones to plan and work with our help of course but that we are not the club.

Mr. Cresswell is planning to organize a debating club among the boys which will be a fine thing for them. So much for the school - If you have any questions please ask them there are so many new things that I can only touch briefly on them and no doubt leave out some that you'd like to know.

We all enjoyed a visit of several days from Mrs. Helmick this past month. The mountain people think the world of her you know and she is in turn devoted to them and loves all Gatlinburg and the school. She always inspires people to higher and better things. At present a Miss Turner is visiting who is also a Pi Phi from Washington D.C. and Evelyn and I think she at one time has been a grand president for the other evening she mentioned something as having happened "during my administration" - It seems that she was the real originator of a school here in the mountains but as she has never been here is greatly interested and charmed with everything.

In two weeks Gatlinburg and our school is to have a fair (the first one) on the school
grounds - They are being held all over the county this month and will be a fine way to bring the people together and give them some new ideas. The school itself will have exhibits (at least we hope to) of school work from manual training & domestic science departments as well as maps writing papers etc. - also livestock farm products & fancy work. My next months letter will tell you about it all. We hope to work in various little things that at present are up in the air.

Now to lighter things! My dears you will
never guess my latest wild escapade for in my wildest flights of fancy about the mountains I never pictured myself going after a still! But that is just precisely what we four teachers did one night in company with the deputy sheriff - our Harrison! It was last week and just before supper of a lovely evening - Busy as bees had we been since school - cleaning our rooms and the rest of the house - so Evelyn suggested that we have a little ride with Harrison in the "back" (two seated buggy) while she and Aunt Lizzie got supper ready - Off we started bareheaded - in light dresses & thin shoes - little dreaming of what was to come! Before we had any more than gotten on the road the conversation had turned to stills and their capture. Harrison
mysteriously confided to us that he was going after one the next night - Of course we girls wanted to go - but that was the night of the club party so we said - why not then and there and the three of us soon had the poor man completely at our mercy and saying we'd stop and get "Prof. Cresswell" he meekly yielded. Of course there was no time for us to stop and dress for the part and anyway we didn't quite realize the wild scramble that was awaiting us. To cut a long story short Mr. C. was charmed & bought a big watermelon while Harrison bought a flashlight &
some gay candy & made several mysterious disappearances. He was perfect in his part the whole evening - so cautious - always whispered - stopped & peered hither and "yonder"! At last we were off down the road towards Sevierville which we followed for about two miles. Then we left the hack Dan & the watermelon and scrambled down to the river. Emily & I in French heels & white pumps had an awful time leaping gracefully from rock to rock as we had to cross the river thusly. I landed at one spot with both feet in the water. That was a small item however & arriving at the other side we plunged through the unbroken wilderness where H. did the Sherlock Holmes act to perfection as stated above. Eventually we struck a faint trail which lead right up a little "branch" in the wildest "holler". For nearly a
mile we jumped scrambled & almost crawled occasionally H. went ahead & then would come back & we'd whisper & proceed silently as before. At last we had whiffs of moonshine - "plumb" strong ones too - & then we came to the spot where was the furnace and several barrels - the furn still itself was gone - H. thought it probably concealed in the laurels nearby while "they" were at work "pulling fodder". Everyone is stripping their corn at present & as soon as that is done the still will be active no doubt & H. will visit them again. It was almost dark when we started back along our wild &
romantic trail. Going across the river was even more disastrous than before & we were all wet to the knees except Abbie. After hitching up Dan we stood around in the dusty dark road in our dripping sodden shoes & garments eating that toothsome melon and how we giggled over the whole thing! Well it was about 9 or 9:30 when we finally got home after binding ourselves to secrecy as to our adventure. Evelyn thought it a wonderful & unusual experience but rather risky as shooting in is no uncommon thing at a raid - and also not a very wise thing for us as teachers to do. She is right of course and we won't go again but we would not have missed it either - not any of it!
I have called at a number of homes and stayed all night Wednesday at a typical cabin - and thoroughly enjoyed it. Have also had some more long tramps and tasted my first (and last) moonshine!

As it is almost time for the mail to go out I must say goodbye and hasten to the store with this letter which I'd love to make twice as long. I have asked my mother to give you the kodak pictures for your meeting and if
the Seattle Pi Phis will forgive me I'm going to ask them to share my letters with you as so far there has not been time for me to write them separately. Perhaps later there will be more opportunities for writing.
Hoping that all is well with each one of you and that the inspiration to write me may come to some of you I am
